body: @rajinisivaram, can you please rebase?

The general approach seems fine. I left one comment and I didn't review the test changes in detail as they will change a bit after the rebase (as a new helper method was added to the test in the previous PR).

I'll try to help with the tests. Have you tested using an IP address like the one you posted that it behaves as you expect? Do I understand correctly that the aim is to define the network interface to bind to?
@ijuma Rebasing now, will submit soon, thanks.

@ijuma I have rebased the PR for KAFKA-3618. Sorry I closed the old one and opened another one since the old one wasn't linked to the JIRA properly. I have addressed the comments on the other one. Thank you for the reviews.
@hachikuji and @granders Thanks a lot for your comments. I addressed all of them. Could you take one more look?
@hachikuji Updated to `public void putTaskConfigs(String connector, List<Map<String, String>> configs)`.

@guozhangwang @miguno @enothereska Please review.

I guess this should get merged last. Might need to rebase after #1277 and #1250 got merged.
LGTM, thanks @SinghAsDev!

@Ishiihara Left a couple minor comments, but mostly LGTM. Thanks for trying to push through the refactor I suggested. It looks like it worked out well for `DistributedHerder`, but maybe a little awkward for `StandaloneHerder`. Considering the complexity of the former, that might be a good trade.
@ewencp Mind taking a quick look at the path resolution API again? I think it's cleaner now
@granders Added include test jars to relevant system test services.
Jenkins failures were unrelated - rebased master and all is passing now.
@granders and @hachikuji Ready for another look.
@miguno @guozhangwang @enothereska Just updated this.
This seems fine to me, but I'll wait for @ewencp to take a look as well.

@rajinisivaram, thanks for the explanation and additional tests. I left some minor comments, it looks good otherwise. I'll leave it to @gwenshap to also take a look and merge it if she's happy with the PR (hopefully you can address the minor comments before they wake up in the US).
LGTM. Merged to trunk.
@mjsax #1277 is merged, could you rebase?
@guozhangwang Rebased. Also added class JavaDoc for TimeWindow.
@gwenshap @ijuma Thank you both for the reviews. I have made the changes suggested. Will wait to see if there are more changes/tests required.
Thanks @mjsax for your patience! LGTM and merged to trunk.
@guozhangwang Just updated this PR. Addressing your comments and rebased to latest trunk.
LGTM
LGTM
@Ishiihara Same as @hachikuji, few minor comments but mostly LGTM.
Won't merge for 0.10.0, perhaps for a later release. The problem is broader than just initialization.
@ewencp Addressed review comments. PTAL.
LGTM. We may want to move some of this into the normal docs given how large this part of the javadocs is getting, but better to get this in _somewhere_ for the next release.
This LGTM, I'll just remove that one extra `echo` during commit
@ewencp Thanks for the review, removed the left over debug output.
LGTM, thanks!
LGTM
I double checked the test and it all looks good. Thanks for your patience @rajinisivaram.
@ijuma @ewencp Thank you for reviewing the other SASL ducktape test PR. Do you mind taking a look at this one too? Thanks.
Thanks for the patience, @mjsax. LGTM!
@guozhangwang @ijuma @miguno could you please have a look.
cc @gwenshap

@soumyajit-sahu Thanks for adding the tests. The question was whether you tested that the broker works correctly (you can produce to and consume from it) with link-local IPv6 addresses after your change (I understand that we won't fail during validation, but I was looking for a bit more than that).
Also, I just noticed that this PR targets the 0.9.0 branch. It should target trunk instead.
LGTM
@ewencp Addressed review comments. PTAL.
@ewencp I think this is ready for a more careful review now
LGTM.
LGTM, thanks @Ishiihara!
Superceeded by https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1294.  This PR **should not** be merged.
@enothereska : Can you please close this PR?
LGTM
@becketqin Will you have a chance to rebase this? I think this would be really nice to have in 0.10. I am happy to help rebase it too.

@hachikuji Mind taking a look?

It's possible some default timeouts will need tuning, so I'm doing a full run here: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/53/console
Just to clarify, this isn't a protocol bump because the underlying byte remains the same. Correct?

@gwenshap Yes. The underlying implementation stays the same. This is just code cleanup that improves the autogenerated protocol docs and makes sure all booleans in the protocol are implemented the same.
@granders Thanks for taking this. Left a couple minor comments, but overall LGTM.

@ewencp @Ishiihara Thanks for taking a look. I realized that this patch breaks prefetching since we now send the fetches before updating the position. I'm looking into options to fix this. Please avoid merging for now.
LGTM
retest this please

@hachikuji Seems like we might need some unit tests that validate behavior of auto offset commits and wakeup exceptions when they potentially clash since that combination seems to be really tricky to get right.
Sorry for this bad experience...

@dpkp Thanks for testing and catching this, and sorry! This is an unfortunate case not easily caught by our testing since we don't have anything automated post-generation of release tgz. I tested both release tgz files manually and this looks good.

@ewencp @Ishiihara The patch I was working on was getting a little too complex/risky, so I decided to go with something a bit simpler. Let me know if it seems reasonable. Also, agreed on improving test coverage.
@vahidhashemian: Sorry for the confusion.  I suppose that the crunch time before the upcoming 0.10 release was the reason for this.

@vahidhashemian: I checked the [Kafka JIRA ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3614) quickly.  It looks like there was a glitch in the GitHub <-> JIRA integration, as the original PR (https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1262; was filed 2 days prior to yours) was not detected and tracked by the ASF JIRA, so it looked as if no one had started working on it yet.

In any case, thanks for your help!

First, thanks for the cleanup. It looks fantastic.
The latency reduction is mostly from use of "hasTopicMetadata" when possible instead of "getTopicMetadata"? Or am I missing another performance win?

Did you do before / after tests for latency, or is this "common sense optimization"? (either is fine, but if you have numbers, do share...)

And last but not least, should this go into 0.10.0 branch? It looks like a harmless refactoring, but I have to admit that anything that touches the metadata cache is a bit scary and we may want to give this more time to "bake". @ijuma - your thoughts?
FYI I hit this issue with a fairly complex kstream job, the way I worked past it is by ramping up the number of worker threads.

bump for review.

Re: ApiVersion -- I noted in KIP-57 that I think this would only apply to people who (1) run trunk, (2) upgraded to v1 message storage, (3) use LZ4 compression. I'm skeptical that there are any users that fall into all 3 categories. Thoughts?
@mjsax @miguno No problem at all. I figured something was going on as I didn't see @miguno's PR mentioned on the JIRA even though it was submitted before mine. Hopefully, this won't happen again :)
@rajinisivaram : Thanks for the patch. Could you also add a description of the latest SASL authentication protocol in protocol.html?

@ijuma and @fpj - sorry for not noticing it is a 0.9.0.0 patch and backport of another change. 

LGTM
LGTM.

@gfodor Your approach works if the topology is composed of multiple disconnector sub-graphs (i.e. sub-topologies); given a complex topology that is a single connected component, we cannot break it into multiple threads, and hence the issue still retains. We are working on a more general solution for this issue now.

@ewencp It's quite cumbersome, but I've added some test cases as suggested. I think this covers the main cases this patch is about, but there's plenty of room for additional tests. Do you think we should do them here?

@ewencp Thanks for review! here are a few answers:

version bumping... I don't think it really matters in this case given how comparison works? (see my previous version-related comments)
1. Yes, we want double commit here
2. PR/branch builder would've caught this no matter irrespective of the branch. Even a run of just the sanity checks would have caught this particular issue.

Running sanity checks here:
https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/425/console

Full build here:
https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/54/console
@kawamuray We do not have `retest this` in apache jenkins yet, if you want you can close / reopen the PR to trigger another jenkins test to see if it is transient.
@ewencp Sanity checks now pass
@granders thanks for fixing this.
@fpj This was merged by Gwen. Can you please close the PR? (only PRs to trunk are auto-closed sadly).

Can you do `maxTimeToBlock = Math.max(maxTimeToBlock - (endWait - startWait) / 1000000, 0)`? Otherwise, LGTM.

@ijuma Can you take a look?

@granders Overall looks nice; easy transition without much overhead at each call. I'm having trouble running unit tests. First, I think we missed a `memory_profiler` dependency for the tests. Second, there is a reference to `kafkatest_unit_test.directory_layout.check_project_paths` where the `kafkatest_unit_tests` part of the path is missing the trailing `s` and there's an issue finding a template called `sample`. Also, you might want to go with something a bit less verbose (and less tab-completion-killing) than `kafkatest_unit_tests`. Maybe just `tests/kafkatest/unit` or something like that?

Also, I assume we'll want to kick off a full test run before merging this since it's a pretty substantial change? And you might want to check pre- and post- patch `--collect-only` output to make sure we didn't accidentally lose any tests to syntax errors or anything like that.

@ijuma Yes, I was able to produce and consume after this change on the machine that had % character in its ipv6 address.
I will close this PR, and open a new one targeting trunk.
@ijuma No. It seems that we should record waitTime before TimeoutException is thrown.
Thanks for confirming. It would be good to fix that as part of this PR too.
New PR (targeting trunk) submitted: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1305
Thanks. It would be good to have some tests where`%` is used incorrectly. For example, what if it appears multiple times or if a `:` appears after it (but before a `]`).

It doesn't look like those cases will be possible in real scenario. The % sign is a separator only bound to occur once, and the characters following the % would either be numerals (on Windows) or 'eth'+numeral (on Linux). Below is the rule for it to occur:

# 

When an address is written textually, the zone index is appended to the address, separated by a percent sign (%). The actual syntax of zone indices depends on the operating system:

the Microsoft Windows IPv6 stack uses numeric zone indices, e.g., fe80::3%1. The index is determined by the interface number;
most Unix-like systems (e.g., BSD, Linux, OS X) use the interface name as a zone index: fe80::3%eth0.
alternatively, on BSD based operating systems (including OS X), a numeric zone index can be used in the second 16-bit word, e.g.: fe80:1::3

The reason we validate is to catch mistakes. If we assume people won't make mistakes, we don't need any validation. :) I am aware that `%` should only appear once, that's why I suggested the IP address should fail validation if it appears multiple times.
@ijuma The unit tests have been added and the two issues (a new variable & record waitTime before throwing TimeoutException) have been resolved. Can you take a look?
LGTM
Full build had one failure, but its an existing transient issue. LGTM, thanks @granders!

I agree, but if we want to cover all grounds, then we should use a standard library to help us parse the IPV6 addresses. Something like https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/InetAddressValidator.html.

Let me know what you think, and I could try to incorporate it.
@hachikuji Not a big deal. Just some clean up.

@ijuma Ok
@gwenshap Thanks for reviewing and merging!
